awd_titl_txt: Determining the rates and conditions of subduction initiation beneath the Samail Ophiolite
awd_abstract_narration:
Subduction zones are the primary loci of chemical exchange between the surface and the deep Earth. Understanding how subduction initiates and evolves is important for characterizing the nature of this exchange. The geological record contains a rich archive of subduction initiation in the form of ophiolites, which are pieces of oceanic crust and mantle emplaced on continents. These ophiolites often contain a thin veneer of rocks smeared out and welded to their base (“metamorphic soles”) that are thought to represent the first increments of subducted material in a newly formed subduction zone, i.e., when a plate first begins to sink. This proposal seeks to characterize the thermal and chemical record of these earliest subducted rocks along the base of Samail Ophiolite (Oman/UAE) to determine the rates and conditions at which subduction started in the Samail system. These data will be critically tested against geodynamic models to understand the tectonic settings and physical parameters leading to subduction initiation. The data will also be used to trace the earliest phases of subduction-related chemical exchange between the surface and the deep Earth. The project is spearheaded by two early career scientists; supports the educational, technical, and professional development of two undergraduate students; and funds the development of a virtual museum exhibit about ophiolites for the general public.

The research is expected to identify: i) the duration of high-T metamorphism in the Samail sole, ii) metamorphic conditions and mass flow paths (P-T-t) in the sole, and iii) variations in (i) and (ii) along the length of the ophiolite. Analytical work will be performed on garnet amphibolites previously collected from the Samail metamorphic sole. We will collect garnet, clinopyroxene, and Ti-phase trace-element spots and maps (LA-ICPMS); quantitative garnet and clinopyroxene major-element maps (EPMA); bulk-rock major and trace-element data (XRF, ICPMS); and Raman spectra on strained quartz and zircon inclusions in garnet. These data will be used for conventional, single-element (e.g., Zr-in-titanite), and elastic thermobarometry to characterize P-T paths experienced by each of the studied samples, as well as diffusion modelling of trace- and major-element profiles in garnet and clinopyroxene to constrain T-t histories. These data will also be used to test between order-of-magnitude differences in metamorphic timescales from different geochronological techniques, potentially supporting either long-term “forced” subduction initiation or shorter-term “spontaneous” subduction initiation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Subduction zones are important tectonic features that govern chemical exchange between the surface and deep Earth. Understanding how subduction starts and evolves is important for characterizing the nature of this recycling. The geological record contains a rich archive of subduction initiation in the form of ophiolites, which are pieces of oceanic crust and mantle emplaced on continents. These ophiolites often contain a thin veneer of rocks smeared out and welded to their base (“metamorphic soles”) that are thought to represent the first increments of subducted material in a newly formed subduction zone, i.e., when a plate first begins to sink.

 

Metamorphic soles occur globally beneath numerous ophiolites. Our project sought to characterize the thermal and chemical record of these earliest subducted rocks along the base of the Samail Ophiolite (Oman/UAE), to determine how and how fast subduction started. Previously published geochronology data had suggested a range of possible metamorphic durations spanning an order of magnitude (~1–10 Myr), with data from different minerals (zircon, garnet) and different isotopic systems (U-Pb, Lu-Hf) yielding contrasting interpretations. In this project, we utilized an extensive suite of previously collected metamorphic sole samples, and applied several overlapping techniques on a subset of key rocks, including garnet diffusion speedometry (modelling the duration that each rock could have remained at high temperature) and garnet Lu-Hf isotopic dating (absolute quantification of the timing of high temperature metamorphism). These overlapping data have demonstrated that the duration of peak temperature metamorphism (600–800°C) in the metamorphic sole of the Samail Ophiolite is some of the fastest known in the rock record, spanning <1 Myr and potentially even faster (<1 kyr). Because this metamorphism was so rapid, it requires a heat source unique from other high-temperature metamorphic rocks that occur over much longer time and spatial scales, and suggests that it is related to shear heating as the leading edge of the subducting plate sunk into the mantle. These short timescales are consistent with “spontaneous” subduction initiation, in contrast to previous inferences for “forced” subduction initiation in the Samail system, and our extensive dataset provides a rigorous set of empirical constraints for numerical and geologic models to study this process further.

 

A second key outcome from our project is the identification of significant differences within the metamorphic sole of the Samail Ophiolite. Several previous studies have focused on how similar metamorphic soles are globally, arguing for a relatively homogeneous process to form them. However, our results emphasize that a metamorphic sole can be strikingly diverse even within a single system. This includes changes in the starting rocks that formed the metamorphic sole; changes in the composition of these rocks as they were heated and melted; differences in the peak temperatures that each part of the metamorphic sole experienced; and differences in the absolute time and duration that each portion of the sole underwent metamorphism. The recognition of this variability demonstrates previously unknown complexity within the Samail sole, and by extension other similar rocks globally. We can use these differences to understand the key variables that are important during subduction initiation.

 

This project supported the technical, professional, and career development of three undergraduate students, including two senior thesis research projects (one at Penn State and one at UC Santa Barbara), as well as the professional development of an early career non-tenure-line faculty at Penn State. The project also supported a new collaboration between two early career faculty at rural public state universities (Penn State and University of Maine). The research funded by this work also supported the construction of a museum exhibit about subduction zones, ophiolites, metamorphic soles, and garnet that is currently on display at the Penn State Earth and Mineral Sciences Museum and Art Gallery.

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2024
Modified by: Joshua M Garber
